Ketika KPK di Bawah Kuasa Presiden
05 Nov 2019, 01:00 by Idul Rishan
Idul Rishan Staf Pengajar Departemen Hukum Tata Negara Universitas Islam Indonesia
Jika mencermati Undang-Undang Komisi Pemberantasan Korupsi yang baru (Undang-Undang Nomor 19 Tahun 2019), arah politik hukumnya jelas: mengubah simpul kelembagaan KPK, dari lembaga independen menjadi lembaga pemerintah. Dalam Pasal 3 disebutkan bahwa KPK adalah lembaga negara dalam rumpun kekuasaan eksekutif yang dalam melaksanakan tugas dan wewenangnya bersifat independen dan bebas dari pengaruh kekuasaan mana pun. Tegasnya, pasal itulah "jantung" dari undang-undang tersebut. Melalui ketentuan tersebut, KPK tak ubahnya sebagai mandataris presiden.
Konsekuensinya, KPK berwarna eksekutif. Manajemen kepegawaiannya pun wajib bercorak eksekutif, dari status penyidik sampai promosi dan mutasi yang tunduk pada regulasi aparat sipil negara.
Pasal 3 juga menginisiasi lahirnya pasal-pasal lain yang menyangkut Dewan Pengawas. Perangkat ini mempunyai kewenangan yang superior, bahkan dibekali kuasa pro justitia. Meskipun dalam pasal itu KPK diberi "irah-irah" independen dalam melaksanakan tugas dan wewenangnya, kenyataannya sulit dibenarkan. Relasi kuasa yang bersifat vertikal dengan presiden cenderung membuat KPK berayun menjadi "dependen".
Studi Oce Madril (2018) menunjukkan bahwa tak ada lembaga di bawah kuasa presiden yang kinerja dan prestasinya baik dalam memberantas korupsi, seperti Badan Pengawas Kegiatan Aparatur Negara di bawah Sukarno dan Operasi Tertib di bawah Soeharto.
Undang-Undang KPK baru menjadi simbol dekadensi dalam praktik demokrasi di Indonesia. Betapa tidak, pembentukan KPK merupakan kritik atas lemahnya independensi kepolisian dan kejaksaan dalam pemberantasan korupsi. Mengingat kepolisian dan kejaksaan secara hierarki berada di bawah kuasa eksekutif, KPK hadir sebagai lembaga independen.
Susan Baer (1988) menulis bahwa kehadiran lembaga independen muncul sebagai pemicu atas cara kerja lembaga konvensional yang dinilai tak lagi efektif. Tesis Baer ini diperkuat oleh Ackerman (2000), yang menyatakan lembaga independen merupakan gejala autokritik terhadap pemisahan kekuasaan secara konvensional antara eksekutif, legislatif, dan yudikatif.
Demikian halnya selepas transisi politik bergulir di Indonesia. Zainal Mochtar (2016) mencatat ketidakpercayaan publik kepada lembaga negara yang telah ada mendorong lahirnya lembaga independen untuk melaksanakan tugas dan diidealkan memberikan kinerja baru yang lebih tepercaya.
Penempatan KPK di bawah kuasa presiden justru menjadi sangat kontraproduktif terhadap respons percepatan kebutuhan demokrasi. Sudah menjadi rahasia umum bahwa korupsi di sektor eksekutif menjadi agenda yang tak luput dari kinerja KPK selama ini. Suap di pelbagai sektor kementerian hingga korupsi kepala daerah seolah-olah sebagai penanda bahwa kekuasaan eksekutif menjadi anasir yang terus memberikan ancaman dari perilaku elite politik. Bisa dibayangkan, sebagai institusi yang berada di bawah kuasa presiden, KPK bisa terjebak dalam konflik kepentingan.
Dalam beberapa jajak pendapat media cetak dan elektronik, pembentuk undang-undang mengklaim bahwa politik hukum Pasal 3 itu merupakan tindak lanjut atas Putusan Mahkamah Konstitusi Nomor 36/PUU-XV/2017. Sebenarnya ada empat Putusan MK lain yang juga memberikan penafsiran atas kedudukan dan independensi kelembagaan KPK, seperti putusan Nomor 012-016-019/PUU-IV/2006, Nomor 37-39/PUU-VIII/2010, Nomor 5/PUU-IX/2011, dan Nomor 49/PUU-XI/2013. Empat putusan itu berada pada satu napas yang sama bahwa KPK merupakan lembaga independen dan mempunyai sifat penting dalam struktur kekuasaan negara. Membaca kondisi demikian, lantas putusan mana yang harus diikuti? Menurut saya, Putusan Nomor 36/PUU-XV/2017 tidak sepenuhnya dapat dijadikan alasan pembenaran pembentukan Pasal 3.
Ada dua alasannya. Pertama, perkara ini tidak menguji pasal-pasal dalam Undang-Undang KPK terhadap Undang-Undang Dasar, melainkan menguji Pasal 79 ayat (3) Undang-Undang Nomor 17 Tahun 2014 tentang MPR, DPR, DPD, dan DPRD terhadap Pasal 28D ayat (1) UUD 1945. Ihwal pengajuan perkara ini semata-semata untuk memperluas kewenangan DPR guna melaksanakan fungsi pengawasan melalui hak angket, bukan dalam konteks perubahan format kelembagaan KPK. Mengingat KPK melaksanakan fungsi-fungsi eksekutif, hak angket dapat digulirkan sepanjang tidak mendistorsi fungsi penyelidikan, penyidikan, dan penuntutan.
Kedua, dalam teori interpretasi konstitusi, David A. Strauss (2011) mempopulerkan penafsiran "konstitusi yang hidup". Menurut dia, dalam konteks penemuan hukum, majelis hakim dimungkinkan mengubah pendiriannya atas putusan-putusan sebelumnya sepanjang menyebutkan alasan perubahan dalam amar putusannya. Dalam Putusan No. 36/PUU-XV/2017, tak ada satu alasan pun di dalam amar putusan yang menegaskan bahwa majelis hakim mengubah pendiriannya atas empat putusan terdahulu. Dengan demikian, Pasal 3 Undang-Undang KPK baru menjadi materi yang layak diujikan di MK.
text:
When the KPK is Under the Authorization of the President
05 Nov 2019, 01:00 by Eid Rishan
Eid Rishan Teaching Staff at the Department of Constitutional Law, Islamic University of Indonesia
If we look at the new Corruption Eradication Commission Law (Act No. 19 of 2019), the legal political direction is clear: change the institutional node of the KPK, from an independent institution to a government agency. Article 3 states that the KPK is a state institution within the group of executive powers which in carrying out its duties and authorities is independent and free from the influence of any power. Strictly speaking, this article is the "heart" of the law. Through these provisions, the KPK is like a presidential mandate.
Consequently, the KPK is an executive color. The staffing management is also required to be executive, from investigator status to promotions and transfers that are subject to the regulation of the state civil apparatus.
Article 3 also initiates the birth of other articles concerning the Supervisory Board. This device has superior authority, even it is equipped with pro justitia power. Although in this article the KPK was given an independent "role" in carrying out its duties and authority, the reality is difficult to justify. The vertical power relations with the president tend to make the KPK swing as "dependent".
The Madril Oce Study (2018) shows that there are no institutions under the authority of the president whose performance and achievements are good in eradicating corruption, such as the State Apparatus Supervisory Agency under Sukarno and the Orderly Operations under Suharto.
The new KPK Law has become a symbol of decadence in the practice of democracy in Indonesia. Imagine, the formation of the KPK is a criticism of the weak independence of the police and the prosecutor's office in eradicating corruption. Because the police and prosecutors are hierarchically under the executive power, the KPK is present as an independent institution.
Susan Baer (1988) writes that the presence of independent institutions appears as a trigger for the workings of conventional institutions which are considered to be no longer effective. Baer's thesis is reinforced by Ackerman (2000), who states that independent institutions are a symptom of autocritics of the conventional separation of powers between the executive, legislative and judiciary.
Likewise after the political transition in Indonesia. Zainal Mochtar (2016) notes that public distrust of existing state institutions encourages the birth of an independent institution to carry out its tasks and is expected to provide new, more reliable performance.
The placement of the KPK under the power of the president has become very counterproductive to the response to accelerating democratic needs. It is common knowledge that corruption in the executive sector is an agenda that has not been spared by the performance of the KPK so far. Bribery in various ministerial sectors to the corruption of regional heads seems to be a sign that executive power is an element that continues to pose threats from the behavior of the political elite. It can be imagined, as an institution under the authority of the president, the KPK could be trapped in a conflict of interests.
In several print and electronic media polls, the legislators claim that the legal politics of Article 3 is a follow-up to the Constitutional Court Decision Number 36 / PUU-XV / 2017. Actually there are four other Constitutional Court Decisions which also provide interpretation of the position and independence of the KPK's institutions, such as decisions Number 012-016-019 / PUU-IV / 2006, Number 37-39 / PUU-VIII / 2010, Number 5 / PUU-IX / 2011, and Number 49 / PUU-XI / 2013. The four decisions are in the same breath that the KPK is an independent institution and has important characteristics in the structure of state power. Reading such conditions, then which decisions should be followed? In my opinion, Decision Number 36 / PUU-XV / 2017 cannot be fully used as a justification for the establishment of Article 3.
There are two reasons. First, this case does not examine the articles in the KPK Act against the Basic Law, but examines Article 79 paragraph (3) of Law Number 17 of 2014 concerning MPR, DPR, DPD, and DPRD against Article 28D paragraph (1 ) 1945 Constitution. The matter of filing this case is merely to expand the authority of the DPR to carry out the supervisory function through a questionnaire, not in the context of changing the institutional format of the KPK. Considering that the KPK carries out executive functions, the questionnaire rights can be rolled out as long as it does not distort the functions of investigation, investigation and prosecution.
Second, in the theory of constitutional interpretation, David A. Strauss (2011) popularized the interpretation of "living constitution". According to him, in the context of legal discovery, the panel of judges may change their position on previous decisions as long as they state the reasons for the changes in their ruling. In Decision No. 36 / PUU-XV / 2017, there is not one reason in the ruling which states that the panel of judges has changed its stance on the four previous decisions. Thus, Article 3 of the new KPK Law becomes material worth testing in the Constitutional Court.
